paragraph.htmltext:
Purpose and scope

The given descriptions in the complete transportation process are based on 'Lithium Batteries - Transport and Packaging Instructions' from Recharge by Marco Ottaviani

Throughout the whole battery life cycle components (cells, modules, packs) are transported between production plants and from production plants to the recycling plants. The transported components can be new, used or damaged.

This process uses a general overview of a transportation process for the different type of transport supplemented with specific information for the transport of each type of component (normal cells, damaged cells, â€¦ ). The information is based on the main transportation legislations for land, air and sea transport and gives together with requirements and legislations templates and symbols which can be used during this process.

Test requirements

Each cell, module or pack is of the type proved to meet the requirements of each test of the Manual of Tests and Criteria, Part III, sub-section 38.3.

Modules and packs shall be of a type proved to meet the testing requirements of the Manual of Tests and Criteria, Part III, sub-section 38.3, irrespective of whether the cells of which they are composed are of a tested type.

Manufacturing Quality Control Programme Requirements

Only cells and batteries which are manufactured under a quality management program may be transported. This program includes:

  • Description of the organizational structure
  • Responsibilities of personnel with regard to design and product quality
  • Inspection and test instructions
  • Quality control instructions
  • Quality assurance instructions
  • Process operation instructions
  • Process controls, including relecant activities to prevent and detect internal short circuit failure during manufacture of cells
  • Quality records, such as inspection reports, test data, calibration data and certificates
  • Test data shall be kept and made avaimable to the competent authority upin request
  • Management reviews under quality management programme
  • Document control and revisions
  • A means for control of cells or batteries that are not conforming to the type tested
  • Training programmes and qualification procedures for relevant personnel
  • Procedures to ensure that there is no damage to the final product

Note: In house quality management programmes may be accepted. Third party certification is not required but the procedures listed above shall be properly recorded and traceable. A copy of the quality management programme shall be made available to the competent authority upon request.

Protection from short cirquit

Cells, modules and packs must be protected so as to prevent short cirquits. This includes protection against contact with conductive materials within the same packaging that could lead to a short circuit.

Training requirements

Personnel shall be trained in the contents of dangerous goods provisions commensurate with their duties and responsibilities, before assuming responsibilities.

Road and maritime regulations allow employees, for which required training has not yet been provided, to perform functions under the direct supervision of a trained person.

Where the carriage of dangerous goods involves a multimodal transport operation, the personnel shall be aware of the requirements concerning other transport modes.

(*) For small excepted batteries, IATA require that any person preparing or offering cells or batteries for transport must receive adequate instructions on these requirements commensurate with their responsibilities.

General regulation and classification

Regulations concerning international transport of lithium batteries are based on the recommendations of the United Nations Committee of Experts on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. Note that these regulations are subjected to changes.

Classification of lithium cells and batteries for transport under the regulations is based on the UN Manual of Tests and Criteria, chapter 38.3.

Lithium batteries in vehicles

UN3171 Battery-powered vehicles

This entry only applies to vehicles powered by lithium ion batteries which are transported with these batteries installed. For the purpose of this special provision, vehicles are self-propelled apparatus designed to carry one of more persons or goods. Examples of such vehicles are electrically-powered cars, scooters, three and four-wheeled vehicles or motorcycles, battery-assisted bicycles (e bikes), wheelchairs, lawn tractors, boats and aircraft. Examples of equipment are lawnmowers, cleaning machine, model boats and model aircraft.

Hybrid electric vehicles powered g both an internal combustion engine and lithium batteries transported with the pattery(ies) installed must be consigned under the entries

  • UN 3166 Vehicle, flammable gas powered od
  • UN 3166 Vehicle, flammable liquied powered, as appropriate.

State of charge

When shipped in bulk (three or more packs), the battery should be at partial-charge state. The module should be at a maximum SOC of 50% in order to limit the energy available to drive faults and ensure extended storage life prior to self-discharge precipitating issues from low cell voltages.

Damaged packages

Packages that have been crushed, punctured or torn open to reveal contents shall not be transported.

reqs.refReq_tag: UN Manual of Tests and Criteria
UN Manual of Tests and Criteria

paragraph.htmltext:
Testing before transportation

The UN Manual of Test and Criteria, chapter 38.3 describes the test to which the cells, modules or packs need to be subjected before they can be transported. The tests are designed to check how the components react under transportation conditions like pressure drops, vibration etc. The manual gives 8 tests:

  • Altitude simulation
  • Thermal test
  • Vibration
  • Shock
  • External short circuit
  • Impact
  • Overcharge
  • Forced discharge

The manual describes for each test the purpose, procedure and the requirements for the test results.

Note that the type of testing, needed sampling can depend on the size of the battery or battery assemblies. Information on required tests for a certain battery can be found in the standard

Structure of the process

  • The first part of the process handles the preparation of the transportation and gives information on how to pack the components, the labelling, documentation for each of the 3 ways of transportation
  • The second part handles about the transportation itself: loading and unloading, storage during transportation, transport in lorry, by ship and by air.
